alt-summary-body.p: U.S. stock indexes rose in light trading Tuesday, highlighted by strength in small-company and financial stocks.

headline.main-hed: U.S. stock indexes rose Tuesday, highlighted by strength in small-company and financial stocks.

summary-body.p: U.S. stock indexes rose in light trading Tuesday, highlighted by strength in small-company and financial stocks.

headline.deck: Dow Industrials Rise For Third Straight Session

article-body.p: U.S. stock indexes rose in light trading Tuesday, highlighted by strength in small-company and financial stocks.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 27.48 points, or 0.2%, to 16808.49. The Dow had waffled between gains and losses early in the session before turning higher in the afternoon to post a third-straight gain.
The S&P 500 index tacked on 4.21 points, or 0.2%, to 1941.99 and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 16.13 points, or 0.4%, to 4337.23.

Small-company stocks outperformed the broader market for a second straight session, a sign that investors were willing to accept more risk. The Russell 2000 index of small-cap companies rose 0.8% to close at the highest level since April 3.

Financial stocks were the strongest of the 10 S&P 500 sectors, followed by other sectors tied closely to economic growth, like consumer discretionary and industrials. Defensive sectors, including utilities and telecommunications, eased.

Sal Arnuk, co-head of trading at brokerage firm Themis Trading, said activity remained light. "There are very few catalysts right now," Mr. Arnuk said. "The more experienced traders know there's a time to sit on your hands, and this is one of them."
Tuesday marked the 42nd-straight session the S&P 500 closed up or down less than 1%, the longest such streak since 1995, according to WSJ Markets Data Group.

"We're seeing the same thing we've seen for a long time, which is very little movement in the market," said Joe Peta, managing director of Novus Partners, which advises hedge funds and institutional investors. "People say they are nervous, but they are still putting bids in [for stocks] when prices drop."

Investors were reluctant to take a stand ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy statement on Wednesday. The Fed is widely expected to announce another $10 billion reduction in its highly-stimulative bond-buying program to $35 billion a month. But investors will be looking for any changes in the Fed members' economic projections that might influence policy going forward.
On the economic front, new residential construction and building permits, which are an indicator of future construction, fell more than expected in May.

In addition, data showed that retail inflation rose slightly more than expected, which helped weigh on Treasury prices. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note settled at a five-week high of 2.653%, up from 2.599% late Monday. Yields rise as Treasury prices fall.

Jonathan Golub, chief U.S. market strategist at RBC Capital Markets, said the inflation data was encouraging, as it suggested the economy was moving farther away from any worries about deflation. "The equity market is applauding [the inflation data], because it confirms that economic growth is healthy," Mr. Golub said.
He noted that financial stocks tend to benefit when inflation and interest rates start increasing from low levels, because the higher rates increase the profits banks can make off loans.
Recent jitters over the turmoil in Iraq appeared to ease, as oil prices and some safe-haven investments, like gold, pulled back.
Crude-oil futures fell 0.5% to settle at $106.36 a barrel. Gold futures lost 0.3% to $1,271.70 an ounce to snap a six-session win streak.

"We've turned our attention away from the Middle East for the moment," said Joseph Quinlan, chief market strategist at U.S. Trust, Bank of America Private Wealth Management. "We're very cognizant of the geopolitical risks, but we're expecting a continued grind higher" for stocks in the short term, he said.

media.media-caption: MarketWatch's Sital Patel joins WSJ's Michael Casey on the News Hub to discuss the markets today, as stock futures fall and May housing shows low numbers, along with top stocks to watch. Photo: Getty

list-item.link: Morning MoneyBeat: Fed Sidesteps the Spotlight

highlight.link: Iraqi Kurdistan Plans to Increase Oil Exports

article-body.p: European stocks edged higher, with the Stoxx Europe 600 up 0.3% after shedding 1.3% in the past two sessions.
Asian markets were mostly lower, as China's Shanghai Composite declined 0.9%. Japan's Nikkei Stock Average bucked the trend by rising 0.3%.
The dollar gained ground against the euro and the yen.

media.media-caption: MarketWatch's Sital Patel joins WSJ's Michael Casey on the News Hub to go over the three top stocks to watch today, including AT&T, Apple and General Motors. Photo: Getty

article-body.p: In corporate news, Tesla Motors climbed 3.1% after New Jersey's General Assembly passed a bill to allow the company to sell vehicles through up to four company-owned stores.

Netflix advanced 3.1% after analysts at Morgan Stanley turned bullish on the stock, citing the company's long-term profit potential and belief that revenue will rise past current expectations. The firm now rates Netflix overweight, up from a previous rating of equal weight.

Kindred Healthcare Inc. dropped 3% after the company increased its offer to buy the home health and hospice company Gentiva Health Services to $14.50 a share from $14 a share, raising the value of the deal to about $534 million in cash. Gentiva's stock rallied 5.1%.
Write to Tomi Kilgore at tomi.kilgore@wsj.com
